The order of a group $G$, denoted as ord $G$, is defined as the number of elements in $G$ if $G$ is finite. If $G$ is infinite, its order is said to be infinite.
An A-module M is said to be finitely generated if it admits a finite system of generators. It is also referred to as a finite A-module.
Does the concept of a/an Order of a group need to be defined for a definition of a/an Finitely generated module to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The concept of a finitely generated module involves a module M over a ring A that can be generated by a finite number of elements from M. This definition focuses on the ability to express every element of M as a linear combination of a finite set of generators with coefficients in A. It does not inherently involve any properties of groups or the concept of the order of a group, which pertains to the number of elements in a group. The order of a group is a concept used in group theory to describe the size of the group, either finite or infinite, and does not directly influence the definition or understanding of what it means for a module to be finitely generated. Therefore, the concept of the order of a group is not necessary to define or understand a finitely generated module.
